text.title: part3_Murray Hill on the life and versatility of a New York drag king

p: MH: Quite a few. I will say my public girlfriend Is Dirty Martini; my Hollywood wife. My Beard, so to speak.

p.hi: DS: The New York Times article made it seem like you are embodying this character, that you have become him, and have no personality outside of Murray Hill.

p: MH: Well, I don’t know about that. I think of myself as an entertainer and there are definitely some old school references, and I try to make it a little easier for people and say I am a comedian. I think people have an easier time understanding what that is.

p.hi: DS: Do you consider yourself transgendered?

p: MH: I really don’t label myself. It’s a conscious—possibly political—decision and I try not to be labeled by gender.

p.hi: DS: Do you consider yourself butch?

p: MH: I consider myself a tough guy. Butch is another label that doesn’t sit well with me.

p.hi: DS: Because it denies your femininity as well?

p: MH: No, just because people like to put narrowing labels on sexuality. I try to challenge that.

p.hi: DS: Do you surprise yourself with your sexuality?

p: MH: What surprises me is I’m often in a lot of uncomfortable situations as Murray, and it surprises me how accepted I am in certain places. It’s mind-blowing. What I do find surprising is when I go to a wedding, and then all the gender-sexuality issues are in a neon shining light, and that’s when I’m like, ‘Whoa!’ I really can say I think of myself as what I am, and I don’t try to put that in a box. But when I go to a wedding, for example, I’m like, “Agh!” for the way I’m treated, looked at, talked about.
head: Drag as performance art for women

p.hi: DS: You don’t like the phrase drag king, is that correct?

p: MH: No, somebody said that—The New York Times wrote an article about me and they made it seem like I don’t like the phrase ‘drag king’. What I tried to explain to them is that I don’t like to be labeled as anything that people form a very narrow viewpoint about. This goes for drag king, this goes for anything else. When you say ‘drag king’ it’s a very specific thing.

p.hi: DS: What is a drag king?

p: MH: A cross-dresser who does some kind of performance, and I think I am much more than that. I really hammered the press about this and I finally got to a point where I think when people assume that somebody is queer, or different, or trans, they always want to put something before their name. And that is what drag king has been. Why can’t you just call me a comedian like Jerry Seinfeld is called a comedian?
